ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: basics of algorithms
P=NP, DP, D&C, Greedy etc

I learned very little from this course. It is actually shocking how little I learned give how ambitious the syllabus seems. I think because this course is very proof-based we spend a lot of time learning weird proof techniques rather than learning algorithms in a meaningful way that would help is in our futures. Also, Glenn is an atrocious professor. His lectures are all over the place and barely make any sense. This only compounded a general sense of disorientation that I felt the entire semester in this class.
Algorithms. Got more familiar with dynamic programming. Finally (kind of) understood what NP means.
How to reason about algorithms, complexity and solvability of problems. How to think about the efficiency and correctness of code, and about big questions in mathematics
It helped me develop my problem solving skills.
Knowledge about algorithms and how to think of then in CS terms.

I learned about complexity classes for algorithms, how to verify correctness of algorithms, and practices like divide and conquer and dynamic programming. I also now understand recursion much better than I did in 201

I gained to more thorough appreciation of the important classes of algorithms that computer scientists encounter every day: greedy algorithms, dynamic programming, random algorithms, etc. Also, I learned about the theoretical tools necessary to reason about the correctness and complexity of algorithms.

How to prove correctness of algorithms, stable matching problem, greedy algorithms, minimum spanning tree problems, network flow problems, divide and conquer problems, dynamic programming approaches, P/NP problems.

A broad overview of algorithms and complexity theory. Course covers more content than a typical algorithms class in another school, but does not go into that much depth per se. Topics like greedy algorithms, shortest paths, minimum spanning trees, divide and conquer, dynamic programming, network flow/ max flow and min cut, P vs NP and other classes of problems.

Several types of algorithms. Loop invariant proofs, stable matching, shortest paths, minimum spanning trees, greedy algorithms, maximum flow, dynamic programming, divide and conquer, computational complexity.
Greater confidence in algorithmic design and analysis.
Understanding of algorithmic thinking, including knowledge of basic algorithms, proving algorithm correctness, designing algorithms, evaluating algorithm runtime
Algos
I learned about different algorithms for solving common problems. Also learned about how to evaluate different types of algorithms based on their space and time complexity.
All sorts of algorithms, ranging from greedy to DP or randomized to network flow. Really great to learn how to implement them and prove that they are correct
Greedy algos, DP, divide and conquer, loop invariants, P vs NP, flows
Popular algorithms, verifying the correctness of algorithms, proof by induction, P vs NP, NP-Complete problems, etc.
Developed skills for reasoning about the correctness and runtime of algorithms. Learned about techniques to solve more difficult problems.

I learned about loop invariants as a method of proving algorithms' correctness, Dijkstra's algorithm, greedy algorithms, Gale-Shapley algorithm, Max Flow and Ford Fulkerson algorithm, dynamic programming, divide and conquer, the master theorem, NP vs P, approximation algorithms and randomized algorithms. Most of this class was learning some algorithm or technique and then figuring out how to slightly alter it in order to solve other problems which is satisfying in its own way!
algorithms
I learned how to devise algorithms and prove their correctness
I learned about algorithm verification and complexity categorization (P, NP, etc.). We also briefly covered common problems in Computer Science and algorithms used to approach these problems.
I learned algorithms and how to write basic proofs and proof techniques
I learned about algorithms ranging from Dijkstra's algorithm for shortest paths, maximum flows, NP and NP-complete problems, along with how to prove their correctness using loop invariants.

I became much more comfortable with different algorithm design paradigms (e.g. greedy, divide-and-conquer, dynamic programming, network flow, approximation algorithms, randomized algorithms), canonical algorithms (e.g. Gale-Shapley, Dijkstra, Bellman-Ford, Ford-Fulkerson), more advanced data structures and graph concepts (e.g. Fibonacci heaps, priority queues, minimum spanning trees, min cut, Hamiltonian paths and cycles), computational complexity classes (e.g. P, NP, NP-complete, NP-hard, PSPACE, EXPTIME, ZPP, RP, BPP), NP-complete problems and their reductions, and writing proofs. Practically, this helped me better formulate algorithmic solutions to computer science/software engineering problems.
basic skills for developing and evaluating algorithms
I learned about proofs, invariants, time complexity, and a lot of other stuff.
I developed a greater understanding of different types of algorithms and the thought behind them. Also more about time and space complexity.
Types of algorithms and their hardness classes.
I learned about algorithms

knowledge: How to understand and appreciation fundamental algorithms in computer science. 
skills: how to write algorithmic proofs and to think of CS problems in terms of algorithms and efficiency
insights: how fascinating and important algorithmic theory is to computer science
I developed knowledge of how proving different types of algorithms works. Along with this, I learned various properties of things like minimum spanning trees, flow networks, and other things.
I learned a good amount about different algorithms and proof techniques. Way, way more than is necessary for the industry though.
I gained insights into developing algorithms and proving their correctness.

I learned a lot about various problems and methods of solving them with algorithms and modified versions of them. I got much more comfortable with the concept of traversing data structures and when the use of certain data structures is useful. Also got more comfortable with the concept of runtime analysis for both big O and big theta.
I have learnt to analyze and construct algorithms.

I learned paradigms to solve algorithmic problems such as greedy algorithms and dynamic programming. I also learned more about NP-completeness and approximation algorithms. learned how to use algorithms and data structures efficiently to solve problems
many basic algorithms
Learned general algorithmic strategies including greedy algorithms, maximum flow problems, and divide and conquer approaches.
greedy algorithms, loop invariants, proving correctness, ford-fulkerson flow, P/NP, etc

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: its hard

Strength: PSETs were helpful for exams
Weakness: recorded videos from 2020 were hard to follow - too fast. Also, we got no grades back for our homeworks for the second exam - and Glenn actively ignored questions on Ed inquiring when we will get them back. There was 0 feedback on our work done after mid-March until last exam in May.

The only strength I can possibly see for this awful course is that the pure subject matter (like in the textbook) is interesting. But the poor execution of this course on the part of Glenn makes the course uniquely traumatizing and the content uninteresting. The only way for this class to improve is with a different professor. Glenn is a nice guy, but he doesn't understand how stressful this class is from our perspective as students. By giving us one day to study for the midterm (by making a problem set two days before the midterm) or by having a final a week BEFORE reading period while we have classes including in Algos (that had content relevant to the final exam). His lectures are also very confusing and concepts that can be easily explained are made to be way more complicated than they need to be. He also reversed the grading distribution for some reason during the pandemic (to be 70% exams and 30% psets) which added another level of stress to this course experience.

The tests were hard. But I guess that was just the content. Would have been helpful if the recorded lectures were named after the topics covered in class (though this is specific to online learning). Could have given more examples on how to actually write up a proof/explanation to questions like those that appeared on the hw and exams - still am not sure what the level of detail necessary was.

Strengths: GLENN IS THE BEST. Course has a nice variety of topics without being too broad.
Weaknesses: poorly designed office hours infrastructure and scheduling led to scarcity of resources. Some ULAs were unprepared.

Strengths: Can't think of many.

Weaknesses: Way harder than it needs to be. Way more work than it needs to be.
It's algorithms.  It's hard.  This is the type of class you expect by taking algorithms.  I might make the psets count for more though.  It's kinda rough that 80% of our grade is exams.
Technically, an incredibly good course. Not a lot of student collaboration is encouraged though, which could be good for learning.

Lectures are pretty dry but Professor Glenn does his best to make them interesting. This is one of those classes where you just have to grunt through even though the material is tough and dry, because it is definitely helpful if you are looking to have a career in CS

There's a LOT of material and it isn't always clear what is necessary to know (or even helpful to know, as some of the topics covered in lecture/videos are just never brought up again). 

Also, office hours was set up extremely unintuitively this semester, with extremely long wait times that often resulted in very little help after waiting for ~2 hours. There also was not a queue until a fair way into the semester, so there was always a lot of confusion about how long the wait was? Previous CS classes had already solved this problem with a Google Docs queue (or Rob's really cool web app office hours system, csofficehours.org) so I'm not sure why office hours was so chaotic for this class. 

Also, there was a cheating scandal for the midterm and to me it seemed to be handled really poorly because I (as someone who did not cheat) was terrified at the ensuing series of vaguely ominous, threatening posts that Professor Glenn made on Ed because I was worried that the teaching staff may have thought I had cheated since some of my answers were similar to the homeworks, which was totally allowed since it was open-book, and it was just really really stressful.

I very much liked the style of lecture combining both prerecorded videos that we could watch at our leisure and live virtual lectures where we could ask questions to solidify our knowledge. Also the topics in the later half of the course were very interesting. One weakness in my eyes was that it seemed the discussion on loop invariants went on for too long and it could have been cut down a lecture or two to make more room for the survey of approximation algorithms at the end of the semester.

Strengths: Professor Glenn is meticulous and the problem sets and exams are well-set. Exams are challenging enough to produce a curve that actually looks like a proper curve (whereas in other classes, you have 80% of people getting 90+ on an exam), so you don't have to worry about getting perfect answers or getting a low raw score. In the remote setting, the ability to pause and rewatch lectures makes it easier to understand and follow the lectures, which I think was a problem students faced in past years.

Weaknesses: Professor Glenn speaks like a robot in his recorded videos, which is very unfortunate because it makes it really difficult to understand and follow his train of thought. He spends a lot of effort in making the videos, but I suggest that he not follow a script while teaching. The natural intonations that come with teaching and explaining are lost, which seriously affects the intuitive understandability of the recorded lectures. I have struggled to follow the recorded lectures and find them a pain to watch. It might be better to do more explaining and teaching live. Also, problem sets were not returned on time (HW 4-6 returned after final). There is also inconsistency in grading the homeworks, with some students getting off with mistakes, while some students getting really strict and nitpicky graders.
Strength: having the optionality between attending class and solely viewing the recorded mini videos made learning efficient.

This course has a lot of resources, which is a great thing, but I found it difficult to navigate them sometimes. Especially towards the end, it seemed like there were a lot of videos from sort through when looking for a particular concept. But overall, this course is fantastic-- its remarkable how much Glenn is able to cover while remaining succinct and thorough.

Strengths are that it exposes students to the fundamentals of algorithm design. It also challenges students with some of the most common problems in computer science, which can then be used as a knowledge base for solving more complex issues. Weaknesses are that the pacing is sometimes inconsistent, and the material can sometimes feel like it doesn't flow naturally. Providing a clearer topic roadmap at the beginning of each major unit would provide better clarity and an intuitive explanation for the importance of each concept. Faster grading of homeworks would also provide more instant feedback of progress and areas-of-improvement to students.

Overall I thought that the course was well designed for student learning. The recorded mini lectures on each topic were a nice format for the virtual semester. Professor Glenn was dedicated to student learning and answering student questions. The ULAs were very helpful and I appreciated the problem overview sessions for the psets.
The lectures, recorded videos were good
I thought that the pre-recorded videos were incredibly helpful to look back to. I think that live lectures were sometimes a little long and therefore hard to follow for the entire hour and 15 min.

Strength: good psets and materials 
Weakness: office hours were a mess on the second week of each pset; pre-recorded videos on Thursdays were insanely fast (we would cover an entire live lecture of material which is usually 75 minutes in a 6-minute recorded video sometimes). Live lectures were sometimes very boring and just introduced new topics/examples - I feel like the hard material like difficult proofs should be in love lectures and the easy stuff like examples should be in the pre-recorded videos to make it easier. They also only graded 3/6 psets by the time of our final exam, but honestly it didnt matter that much

The material is pretty interesting and some of the homework assignments were actually somewhat enjoyable if you like thinking about problems. However, I found the lectures pretty boring, and a few problems on the homework/exams felt needlessly tedious and long.

The strengths are definitely the lectures, both the prerecorded ones and the live ones. Professor Glenn does an excellent job of being engaging while also being extremely clear in his proofs and algorithms. Another strength was office hours with Glenn, often times I would be almost there with a solution and just needed him to point out something obvious we had mentioned in class which was nice. Also, he is very kind and always willing to help students. Another strength was the problem sets. They were often fun to do! On the other hand, sometimes I think the problem sets were too short or not difficult enough. This is especially true when we have two weeks to do about 2-3 problems but then the exams consist of 4-5 homework problems with way less time. What would be good if we had more practice homework problems and maybe one more challenging question. Another weakness is probably the exams. While fair in the sense that all the questions are doable, they often got me with the time constraints and had I maybe a few more minutes I'd've been able to finish up some of the questions more cleanly. That being said, the class is curved so its not a big deal.

the beginning of the course is a bit theoretical. I feel like invariants are kind of pointless thing to understand. Learned a good amount --- but wish it wass more focused on different algorithms and less on proof/theory

I think some of the topics are very interesting, but the first half of the semester is kind of boring / a slog. It's also unclear most of the time exactly how specific we needed to be in our proofs and grading could sometimes feel a little arbitrary. I loved Glenn's prerecorded videos, he is an acting icon.

A strength of the course is that it covers much more material than other algorithm courses at peer institutions (according to Professor Glenn). A significant weakness to this aspect is that we do not have enough time in the semester to go through the material so my classmates and I can fully understand what we are expected to learn, especially if the only lecture material on any topic is a seven-minute pre-recorded video packed with dense material with little additional examples, explanation, or discussion.
I thought the videos and live lectures sometimes did not feel cohesive and it look a long time for the grading of psets. This made it extremely hard to keep track of progress.

Strengths: 

- several of the algorithms we discussed were interesting and applicable to the real world
- the recorded lecture format (which Prof Glenn puts a ton of work into) really helps a lot for allowing us to see notes, pause the video, and re-record
- I like that finals and psets end before reading period - it takes a lot of load off us students in terms of staggering workload at the end of the semester.

Weaknesses and improvements:

- I think the lectures could be even more helpful by explaining things not so much in mathematical terms but in laymans terms, that is, by adding more examples with real numbers of lemmas and proofs and theorems in action (showing how we could find intuition for figuring it out ourselves)
- I'm not sure why psets were made from 75% of our grade to 36% of our grade this year, but that made the class much more stressful in what has already been a stressful pandemic year.
- Didn't like how the break day on 4/8/21 was ignored, and that we were still assigned pre-recorded videos to watch

Glenn covers a great amount of material (including things not in the Kleinberg-Tardos text but also from CLRS and other sources) to make the course very valuable in terms of teaching us a wide breadth of the design and analysis of algorithms. However, I do wish there were a more organized form of lecture notes than just the copies of his OneNote markups. I think a more organized LaTeX-style set of concise notes (or even topics) would have helped. The teaching staff was great, but office hours' sign-up and meeting system could be improved. I also wish we spent less time on loop invariants (which became pedantic very quickly) and more time on the topics at the end of the course, e.g. PSPACE, approximation algorithms, and randomized algorithms, since those were very interesting.
Could be improved with more practical applications such as evaluating/writing actual code instead of just pseudocode
Half of the course was Khan Academy (series of pre-recorded videos) which always take more than the time specified on the video to actually watch, learn, and digest.

This course used to primarily based on homework grades and minor exam grades  they switched it last year and I think that was a mistake. You spend a decent amount of time completing the problem sets anyways because they're still the same difficulty, but now they're worth like 3% of your grade. Which is frustrating. Instead now the exams count for a lot more, which I think makes less sense. Also, there needs to be a well established office hours system. There was no queue at the start of the semester and this led to chaos -- or even worse, the queue was on the zoom chat which not everyone could see.

For me it felt like a kind of slow start, getting the meticulous points about loop variants done. I greatly preferred the second half of the course. Sometimes we would go through a proof or something in class for a really long time. It was really hard to stay focused for that long with a switch up in topic or break.

I think that having the short videos were very helpful. In general, maybe it was me but I was very lost in the lectures that I stopped going to them. They were so boring and dense and there were way too many equations. I'm not sure how to fix that in the class, but the class was so exhausting.

Weaknesses: Office hours over zoom sucked and were inefficient. Additionally, the course should work to hire competent ULAs who are able to help with problems
Strengths: Glenn is a fantastic faculty member in the CS department. He clearly cares about the course and his students and is responsive to their needs. I loved the short videos and definitely think they should be integrated into the general course (instead of zoom classes)
Strengths: A lot of the material seems to naturally flow from one another.

This course is just too hard for the required algorithms component of the CS major. Glenn says that he has done reviews of our peer institutions, and that our required algorithms course is significantly harder than theirs. Why? Why does our version of algos have to be significantly harder than Harvard's? It makes absolutely no sense. 

Throughout, it's difficult to understand what exactly you need to know for the exams, and in order to do the homework assignments you often have to pull "widgets" out of thin air or it's impossible to solve them.
Not great for different learning styles
The teaching assistants were really helpful

I think the material was interesting and engaging.  However, the grading scheme feels very unfair. If it could be adjusted to give more weight to the problem sets that take hours upon hours to complete, I feel the grading would be more fair. To make timed tests that contain questions as difficult (and more unintuitive) worth 64% of the grade is unreasonable in my opinion. You can do poorly in the course even if you put in hours of work and effort into it.
Clear expectations of what was required on the problem sets were not given, and then a relatively large amount of points were deducted for such mistakes made
Strengths: learn a lot about different algorithms
class could've been more engaging. quizzes in the middle of the recordings were helpful.

The mini lecture videos were amazing and much appreciated, however the large lecture videos should be supplemented by typed out slides with pre-written examples, because they were still largely disorganized and somewhat messy/difficult to understand.

The collaboration policy for homeworks (as opposed to 366) makes a huge difference and makes the course much more engaging and enjoyable. I think the problem sets could be constructed in a more engaging manner.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: loved the pre recorded videos

First exam was fine - open note, 2 hours - stressful but doable
Second exam: Glenn for whatever reason decided that everyone cheated on the first (despite the median being 66% lol) and made the last exam proctored to the extent that we had to all show IDs, show our room, etc - gave us only 75 minutes closed notes (it was actually like 70 minutes because my proctor wouldn't stop talking but insisted we stop right on time)

First exam was well-adapted for COVID - second exam was unnecessarily strict
Nothing succeeded, this would've been much better in person.
Prerecorded lectures were good. I think the recorded lectures should be named after the topics covered in the lecture to better facilitate review.
Recorded topical videos were awesome. Keep these going forward. They made studying so much more efficient. I wish all lectures were topical and labeled as such.
Needs extreme improvement. Level of engagement = nonexistent.
Lecture system was really good.  I enjoyed only having real lectures once a week.
Great office hours system.
The recorded lectures were so helpful as much of the stuff in this course was very difficult to process in the moment

Recorded lectures were a godsend, as someone who benefitted greatly from being able to pause lecture and take the time to understand a complicated topic

Office hours was a big mess for this class -- easily the least organized/helpful office hours of any CS class that I've taken during pandemic-era Yale (except John's walkthroughs were amazing, though I'm not sure why it took until nearly the end of the semester for them to start being recorded because, at least to me, it seems obvious that the benefits of having these walkthroughs recorded for people who couldn't attend and for people to rewatch FAR outweigh the potential costs of... people being worried to ask questions while being recorded?)

I liked the combination of prerecorded videos and live lectures. One problem was that the first few homework review sessions were not recorded making it harder for students to attend them if they had a conflicting schedule/time zone.

The recording of lectures allowed us to rewind and rewatch certain parts which we found confusing. Having recorded videos also forces Prof Glenn to go straight to the point rather than deviate and go off track, which seemed to have been a problem in past course reviews. Recording the problem overview sessions was done later in the semester, and that was very helpful.
Recorded lectures were very convenient and easy to reference. Grouping them using folders by topic also helped with organization.
I enjoyed the mini recorded lectures on selected topics, it helped with guiding studying with a topic-centered organization. I thought the combination of live and recorded lectures was nice.

The pre recorded videos were incredibly helpful. Office hours were also helpful but I think that it should be common practice to assign all students to a breakout room with other students working on the same problem. I find that talking to other students is sometimes just as helpful as talking to a ULA.
I did not like the recorded lectures, they were usually too fast and I had to spend lots of time figuring out what the professor was trying to say.
The split of lectures and videos was interesting but it worked pretty well. I did find lectures pretty slow and the videos sometimes pretty fast.
recorded stuff
I really liked the pre-recorded videos.

I would say that the most successful accommodations for remote learning were the regular Zoom office hours with ULAs and peer tutors, which often provided crucial help with the difficult homework problems. However, both the asynchronous lectures and pre-recorded lectures need some significant improvement. Since the lecture material was often dry and difficult to engage with, there was rarely more than 30 students attending class, even though 119 students were enrolled. The pre-recorded lectures were even worse, as there was no chance for engagement while covering the material, and complex topics were reduced from multiple lectures to a single seven-minute video. Essentially, we were provided raw definitions for difficult topics without any further discussion, explanation, or examples.
I thought the breakout rooms were helpful.
The recorded lectures (both live and pre-recorded) were fantastic for pausing and playing content back, especially since the material is so information dense.
Please keep the pre-recorded videos!! They were great to re-watch.

I liked the recorded videos and quizzes. Although I definitely had to watch them on .5 speed and rewatch them cuz they were so dense. I really enjoyed the few times in lecture we would go to breakout rooms and brainstorm something.
The use of short videos helped a lot
Having the short videos were helpful.

succeeded: the short videos. amazing. so helpful. please keep them forever.
improved: zoom office hours were unhelpful and awkward
The recorded nature of all the class material was incredibly helpful to accommodate different schedules.

Glenn was definitely my professor this semester who I felt cared the least about COVID's impact on his students. Glenn doubled down on the work, didn't loosen any deadlines, and when people were caught cheating on the first exam he made the second exam shorter in time allowance (but not length), closed-note, and proctored. He spent a couple weeks during the "cheating" incident essentially threatening students on EdDiscussion, telling them they might as well drop the course if they cheated because he would find them. This was around the time that Yale's community was struggling mental-health wise, and it didn't feel right for that to be going on at the same time. 

He also included weekly "videos" we had to watch instead of Thursday lectures. At first I thought this was nice because I wouldn't have to sit through an entire lecture, but he would essentially boil down a lecture's-worth of content into 15 mins of video so I'd find myself rewatching portions very often.
The pre-recorded videos and problem walkthroughs were really helpful.

The testing situation was very unforgiving, at least for the second exam. I did not appreciate the switch from the announced 2 hours within a 24 hour time period to a zoom proctored 75 minute exam at a scheduled time. It was very noisy in my environment while I was taking my exam and I could not focus for the first 30 minutes. To then have this along with the first exam be 64% of the grade seems unreasonable.
Office hours with ULA's sometimes had half-hour wait times, which could have been improved
I liked the structure of classes having one class live and the other class time pre-recorded lectures because it provided more flexibility
more engaging classes, and learning activities. going over problem sets or at the very least the most difficult problem (the one with the highest error rate) would also be helpful
The short videos were excellent! There were great explanations of small topics. They were very well edited and easy to find again later in the course for review.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: kmh
This course is probably preferred to 366, but still somewhat challenging. Required for CS majors, so not much of a choice, but definitely easier than 323 was.
I would not. But, this is a core CS class so you may have to take it. I highly advise against taking it with Glenn.
If you have to take it then take it. It was hard and the tests were awful but you'll live.

YES. As a Computing and the Arts major, this course wasn't required for me. I'm glad I took Algos. If you're CPAR reading this, take Algos. You can't learn this stuff just from reading the textbook, no matter what people say. I'm not a mathy person and this course was fun, challenging, and exciting. Glenn is an absolute master of the material and it shows. He's incredibly prepared, passionate, and positive.
No. This course made me switch out of the CS major and I got an A easily in 223 and all other CS courses. This is an overly complicated class for no reason. Do not take this class.
It's algorithms.  If you're reading this you have to take it.  Honestly it's not as bad as you think it is.  It's still rough though.
Yes, if at all interested in algorithms although it is a required course.
If you are a CS major, yes
I would certainly recommend this course for anyone who is interested in learning or designing new algorithms in the future, as it covers many practical and interesting topics.

Yes, it is a good course on algorithms and goes to sufficient depth to challenge you. The remote nature this semester allows one to follow the course material better. The workload is low, problem sets are only once every two weeks, and take quite a short time to do if you attend the problem overview session. I learnt a good bunch about algorithms although the time spent was less - this is a very time and cost-effective course!
Sure. There's some very cool content you'll cover.
Yes! If you're just considering this course, I'd say go for it-- you'll pick up so many novel concepts that you can apply in a lot of different fields.
I would recommend this course to another computer science student because it is essential for complex computational problem-solving.

Yes, if you are interested in algorithms, by which I would mean rigorous rules for mapping some set of inputs to some outputs. CS majors need to take it, but I think it's a good background for people in stem majors outside of CS as well, as well as qualitatively inclined people outside stem.
Yes
Yes, i would recommend to other students interested in CS.
Yes, wasnt a crazy class in terms of work (maybe 5-10 hours per pset). If you pay attention and actually go to lecture, you will learn everything you need to get a job at youre favorite FAANG.
It will definitely improve your ability to create efficient algorithms, although I found the content somewhat boring.

No, lol
.
.
.
If you're a CS major, you just have to do it. If not, please don't take it

It's a CS requirement. That being said, the material is pretty interesting (with a few exceptions) and the homework assignments are doable. Exams are very tough but curved pretty nicely. Lectures can be boring but they do cover the material fairly well. Overall, it's not a bad course to fulfill the algorithms requirement for CS.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The problem sets are genuinely fun to figure out and the algorithms we learn about are interesting and useful in many different fields. The most annoying part of this course however was loop invariants which is by far the hardest part and it is the first topic we talk about so if you don't like that, don't worry the material gets wayyyy better as you go on. A lot of these topics are also probably really relevant for technical job interviews if that's your thing though I felt it was really satisfying to learn as a subject on its own. That being said, I also shopped 366, Intensive Algorithms, and the lectures seemed much more motivated and rigorous than those of 365. If you have the time to invest in 366 I would definitely take that over this, but this class will still teach you everything you need to know from an introduction to algorithms you really need albeit without as much problem solving practice.
If you really enjoy proof based classes and computer science then honestly it isn't terrible. Otherwise would only take it if required

Yeah, the first half is focused on proving correctness which can feel kind of boring. Most of the time proving correctness is really tedious. Once we got to devising our own algorithms it felt really cool and applicable outside of situations requiring verified programs.

I honestly would not recommend this course to any students, even though the course material is essential for majors in Computer Science. It is disappointing to know that since the topics covered in the class are crucial to a well-rounded education in CS, students will surely be required to take the course, no matter how poor the evaluations are. If someone who is interested in learning about Algorithms is not required to take this course, I would remind them that half our lecture material was covered in a similar manner to a ten-minute YouTube video, and there are many other resources online to gain a similar learning experience as an alternative to taking this course.
Only if you have to. I would never recommend otherwise.
I think I would only recommend it if it was required.

If you're a CS major, you don't have a choice. But don't fret. I was expecting this class to be painfully overly abstract and theory-heavy like CPSC202, but I surprisingly enjoyed it more than I expected. Grounding everything in concrete algorithms made the class more relevant than I expected, and I feel like I have a better understanding of algos, which is definitely needed in the software engineering world.
Yes, simply because it's a very valuable topic for computer scientists and because it covers a good breadth of topics compared to other algos courses.
I would not recommend this course to anyone that doesn't need to take it for their major.

Only if you're a CS major and if it's not with Glenn. It is pathetic that this man is a SENIOR LECTURER in the CS department. Half of the course was basically Khan Academy where you're given anywhere from 2-4 videos that are 5-10 mins each. But they never take 5-10 mins to watch, learn, and digest due to the amount of content packed into the videos and the speed which Glenn goes through the material (he even manages to leave out content somehow). You'll learn more from the TF's problem sessions where he does a far better job at explaining and breaking down the content. I also do not understand why the grading distribution was changed from 25% exams, 75% HWs in previous years to 64% exams, 36% HWs especially during a PANDEMIC. Most importantly, Glenn is an uncompromising prof that hardly listens to the needs of students... maybe it's because he lacks compassion? Who knows...
You probably have to take it. I'd say go to office hours to get the most out of it.
Yes! The material gets more interesting as the semester progresses, the book is useful, and the homework is pretty engaging.
Yes it is required for the major and is very helpful
No, exhausting class

Yes! If it's for the major, duh. If not, and you have any interest in logical, computational thinking, or you want to gain an appreciation for why computer science is so important (just beyond programming), learn the theory behind solving any problem

Yes. The course covers a lot of interesting algorithms that are useful in CS. Furthermore, understanding how to prove these makes it very easy to begin to understand whether your own implementations of algorithms are correct or not.

This is required for the CS major, so take it if you have to but maybe avoid taking it with Glenn. If you aren't a CS major, I honestly wouldn't recommend it unless this area really interests you. Don't expect to do any coding in this class though, it's all proofs.
Needed for the major but would recommend taking it in person if its an option.
Yes, algorithms are a central component of computer science and this course does a good job of introducing you to them.

Maybe. The course material is definitely very interesting and the problem sets were fun to work through despite taking as long as they did, but I did not particularly enjoy the class. Professor Glenn is a nice guy and I think he can be a good teacher, but his expectations are unreasonable at times and his lack of responses on important ed questions was frustrating. I know problem sets take a while to grade, but it was nerve wracking to have only half of our problem sets graded by the second exam. We were not able to review our mistakes on them to avoid them on the exam or even know how well/poorly we were doing in the class so far.
yeah, the content is important for all computer science majors
Yeah it's helpful to learn more about algorithms and you probably have to take it anyway as a requirement
only if you're a cs major since this is a required course.
It's required for the CS major. If you're a CS major take it. Otherwise, don't.
If you need to take it for the CS major, yes. Otherwise, no.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: none
Recorded virtual lecture
Thursdays were taught through recorded lecture. Tuesdays were live and virtual.
recorded lecture and live virtual lecture
Sometimes attended live virtual lectures.
Half recorded lecture, half live virtual lecture
Prerecorded videos posted in lieu of one of the weekly class periods, as well as quizzes to test our knowledge.
Live virtual lectures + Recorded lectures
Recorded pre-lecture videos.
Also recorded lecture
Combination of live virtual lectures, recorded virtual lectures, and recorded virtual office hours and discussions
Thank u
None
Thursdays had recorded mini-lectures.
Live virtual + recorded lectures
Live virtual lecture and recorded lecture videos
We would usually have one live lecture per week, and the other lecture would be replaced by a set of videos covering some topics. All lectures were also recorded.
live viirtual
Half the lectures were pre-recorded videos
Alternating asynchronous lectures and recorded lectures
Live virtual lecture and videos to watch
It was a hybrid recorded lecture and live virtual lecture class (although the live lectures were recorded). I took it entirely asynchronously.
We had live virtual/recorded lecture, live virtual problem set overview sessions, live virtual exam review sessions, and virtual office hours.
live recorded lecture
We also had pre-recorded videos
Also virtual office hours
Recorded videos
Recorded lectures as well
virtual live office hours
recorded clips on material to cover in live lecture
Combined live lectures when I was caught up, and recorded when I was behind
Both recorded and live virtual.
Recorded lecture
he did live lectures on tuesdays (recorded and posted for later viewing) plus prerecorded videos on thursdays
NA
Typically, on Tuesdays there was live virtual lecture and on Thursdays there were pre-recorded videos that we were expected to watch
Recorded Lecture & Live Virtual Lecture
Once a week class was a live virtual lecture. Once a week it was a series of short prerecorded videos.
